title: 13. Specializations of the Apical Surface II: Cilia

vectorData.altText: H1   Specializations of the Apical Surface II: Cilia

found on epithelia specialized to move fluid along their luminal surface 
highly motile, synchronized, finger-like extensions of apical cell membrane
core: microtubules with associated proteins, inc. dynein 
taller than microvilli

very well developed in respiratory epithelia      and uterine tubes 
the tails of sperm are structurally similar to the core of a cilia, and this underlies the mobility of sperm; men with ciliary dyskinesia may have immotile sperm.

respiratory epithelium as seen byscanning electron microscopy
CC = ciliated cell
GC = goblet cell

respiratory epithelium lines the airways that conduct air to the gas-exchange surfaces of the lungs
goblet cells (GC), displaying short, blunt microvilli, produce mucous, which coats the surface

particulate matter in inspired air (e.g. dust) sticks to the mucous coating the surfaces; this cleans the air
cilia beat synchronously toward the pharynx     ; the mucous and dust is swallowed, eliminating the dust
Ciliated Cells Line the Respiratory Tract

luminal surface of the fallopian tube as seen byscanning electron microscopy
CC = ciliated cell
PC = peg cell

Fallopian tubes conduct ova     from the ovaries to the uterus; fertilization may take place along the way
ova incapable of autonomous movement; cilia beat synchronously toward the uterus, helping to propel the ovum, suspended in contained fluid, toward the uterus
peg cells (PC), displaying short, blunt microvilli, secrete nutrients which nourish the egg as it travels
Ciliated Cells Line the Fallopian Tubes
